Award.AwardTitle: IUSE: TSU Wetland Observatory - Reforming Laboratory Instruction and Strengthening Research Experiences for Undergraduate Students in Biological and Environmental Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wetlands are crucial to the health of both our water resources and wildlife. Human-induced environmental changes create serious problems, such as the deterioration of water quality and profound alterations to biogeochemical cycles. Solving these problems requires training a diverse population of students in environmental science. At this time, the lack of available resources and facilities poses severe limitations on curriculum innovation at minority-serving institutions and urban universities. The significance and importance of this project is its potential to answer these challenges by reforming undergraduate laboratory instruction and strengthening undergraduate research experience using a wetlands resource situated on the college campus. The project will improve undergraduate education at Tennessee State University (TSU). It can serve as a model for other campuses hoping to upgrade their undergraduate offerings to include more opportunities for students to learn science by engaging in research opportunities that both advance what is known about the world and contribute to the public good. The long term impact will be to help build a more diverse workforce in biology, ecology and environmental sciences.

The goal of this project is to use the TSU Wetland Observatory as an educational and research platform that supports a series of challenging laboratory activities and course projects involving courses taught by five faculty members in two departments. This project will improve student learning and research experiences in biology, ecology, environmental microbiology, and wetland hydrology. Each year the project will benefit over 250 students in a variety of courses. In addition, the TSU Wetland Observatory will serve as a convenient, safe and meaningful education site for public and high school students. Course materials and data developed in this project will be disseminated through workshops, education meetings, journal publications, and a dedicated website. In so doing the project will broaden the knowledge base regarding effective practices to improve undergraduate STEM learning.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this Targeted Infusion Project grant was to reform the laboratory instruction, strengthen student research experiences, and to improve student learning in biology, ecology and environmental sciences at Tennessee State University (TSU). The specific objectives were to: (1) build a education and research platform, TSU Wetland Observatory, that can be used for student education and research at TSU; (2) reform laboratory instruction by developing research-based laboratory modules and course projects that can be incorporated into the undergraduate curriculum as examples of real-world issues; and (3) disseminate TSU Wetland Observatory information through workshops, site visits, website, conference presentations, and publications.

Intellectual Merit: With the support of this grant, we have established TSU wetland as an outdoor observatory and collected long-term datasets of water quality for student education and research. Three YSI multi-parameter (water pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen, specific conductivity, turbidity) Water Quality Sondes and four HOBO water level data loggers are installed to continuously monitor water quality at TSU wetland. More than ten lab modules and research projects have been developed and used in ecology, environmental sciences, wetland courses. These modules enabled students to learn the use of modern instruments, to gain hands-on research experience by collecting field data and conducting data analysis. Two graduate students were also involved in wetland project and used the data and instruments for their thesis. Students enjoyed the field activities at TSU Wetland Observatory, and were able to learn ecology and biology concepts more quickly. With partial support from this project, seven peer-reviewed journal papers were published. The results of this project have also been presented at local, regional, and national research conferences, and disseminated at TSU day at Capitol and Agricultural Day to the general public.

Broader Impacts:  This project directly reached a large number of under-represented minority students at TSU, a historically black college and university, and improved student learning experiences in biology, ecology and environmental sciences. Over 200 undergraduates at TSU were able to use TSU Wetland Observatory in their formal education, and improved their research skills such as data collection, quantitative data analysis, and report writing. Results were also presented to more than 80 high schools students during two summer camps at TSU wetland, in collaborating with Vanderbilt University. This project created a unique field facility, strengthened curriculum in ecology and environmental sciences, and provided intellectual tools for minority students to examine real-world issues. It helped build a more diverse workforce in ecology and environmental sciences.
